title: AI in Media: Strategy, Creativity, and Change Management | Nicole Castillo, News Corp

rawLines.text: Today on Just Curious, I'm joined by
Nicole Castillo, vice president of
strategic products at News Corp, where
she leads AI strategy across some of the
world's biggest content and information
businesses. But Nicole's also a writer,
a mom, and a creative force of nature.
In this episode, we'll explore how she
blends AI into both her professional and
personal life, from vendor vetting and
business model strategy to writing
Substack posts and bedtime stories with
Chat GPT. Learn how she's building an AI
ROI framework to cut through the noise
of vendor hype, how she's piloting tools
with the real benchmarks for success,
and how she uses AI daily from
streamlining finance operations to
fasttracking LinkedIn posts. Nicole,
welcome to Just Curious.
I am very happy to be here and I'm very
curious how this conversation's going to
go. Appreciate your use of Curious. Um,
Nicole, your bio calls you the Mary
Poppins of product. Can you tell us the
story behind that nickname and how it
connects to your AI journey?
Sure. Um, so Mary confidence of product
happened shortly after I joined News
Corp. I had I don't even remember the
the like exact moment, but I remember
seeing something that caused me to be
like, "Oh, that's totally me." I texted
my old boss and I was like, "Isn't this
me?" And he's like, "Totally." And it
sort of stuck and I I leaned in really
hard because it really is I think
everyone when they think of Mary
Poppins, they're like, "Oh, delightful."
There's something about her that like
you think is fun, but she's a little
like hardedged, but like in a good way,
like the best ways. and she has that
magical bag of tricks and she just
brings a lot of spoonful of sugar and
super califragilistic expeladocious to
everything. And I feel like that's
totally me. Like I feel like if I can
slip in a long word like that into any
meeting and it just is really I think
part of being scrappy, part of being
creative, part of being curious about
the world and bringing people on that
journey. She brings these children
along. I bring people stakeholders along
with me on the magical journey that is
you know creating wonderful products.
Curiosity and creativity obviously
helpful when you're looking at something
new like AI. Tell me how you got
involved in helping News Corp understand
and build a strategy to use AI.
Sadly accidentally. Um but I but I think
it ultimately worked out and and there's
a reason for it. Um I had actually just
come back from my maternity leave for my
second um child, my beautiful son, and
things had changed. I had actually hired
to lead mobile products. And I came back
and I was like, I'm looking to to have
more impact, do more things. And it was
like, well, this new thing AI has become
more of a a thing. Why don't you step
into that? And so I started leaning into
what do we do with AI? And much of my
initial first steps were like just like
uncovering the hype. It's like you're
trying to like like is that real? Is
that interesting? Is that important? Is
that important for us for our business?
And so I got the chance to really fall
into it. But I think especially today
where so much of the impact of AI is on
people and is on experiences.
I'm not saying it's less about the tech.
There is definite need for data
scientists and for people who have this
really deeply technical skill to build
these things, but so much of today is
the democratization of AI and how people
will use it. And I think product
leaders, people leaders are ones to
really help lead this new journey of AI
for themselves, for their companies, for
people within organizations.
Yeah. Why why do media companies
care about AI? And and when I think
about AI, obviously, and I believe News
Corp and Dow Jones have been investing
in AI for a long time, but when we're
thinking about the next generation of
AI, the generative AIs, the agentic AIs,
the combination of traditional AI with
new AI, why do media companies care
about this future of AI?
Well, I think regardless of media or
not, everyone should care because I
think those who aren't moving into AI or
aren't at least thinking about it are
going to be left behind. I think media
companies are more sensitive to it.
There's obviously an IP angle to this.
Large language models are powered by
massive amounts of content to make them
good and many of them have already used
much of the content that is sort of out
there. And so whatever new content is
important to lead the next wave of great
AI solutions and models. So I think you
know media companies have this really
important role to play in the future of
how AI models get built and how they are
getting better and how they'll really
embed into the world. So I think but
regardless I think every company should
consider AI as an important part of
where they take their business. Now it
could be generative it could it could be
something else but I think everyone
should be deeply curious
about how how AI could impact their
companies. Yeah. Uh you work in a
business with many business units. How
do you coordinate AI strategy across so
many brands and businesses, especially
when priorities can differ
much like everyone who has jobs that are
like hurting cats with great care and
intention? Well, I I think, you know, we
are in a really unique organization
where not only do we have these amazing
news brands, but we have real estate, we
have book publishing, and like you said,
there are different business needs that
drive each of those businesses. Even in
within the news businesses, there's
different, you know, business models.
And much of what it is is I'm a big
connector. I connect the teams and the
people that are are doing one thing and
say, "By the way, do you know that this
group is doing it and they're doing it
really well?" and connecting those
people and making sure that they're
aware because ultimately we don't want
duplication of you know if something is
done really well you want to share that
and that's the benefit of working in a
large organization such such as news
corporate somebody can take the lead and
prove out and prove successful or prove
something not successful and share the
lessons learned for that journey or
share the teaching so even you know one
of our smaller business units who might
be able to do more bleeding edge things
with some of the AI models that some
others cannot can still share. Oh, I had
a lot of friction. For instance, you
know, uh sensitive content. Many of the
models have protection or guard rails
against sensitive content. But news
content has sometimes sensitive topics.
And so, how do you get and work with
models when some of those things are
restricted? So, those are like little
small lessons that I heard that in this
one meeting with this one business unit
and I managed to kind of help feed and
filter that through the businesses. So
it's creating that connective tissue
more than it is you know pushing down a
centralized mission and vision. We do
have guard rails and principles in place
on how to as a whole work and exist
within kind of how you you build and use
AI. I don't think there's any benefit to
sort of like having a strong restriction
on you know businesses leaning in and
figuring out what works for them either.
Yeah. What have you learned in terms of
the best ways to facilitate
sharing it? Uh do you have a you know
Slack channel and people are just
dropping ideas in there? Do you set up
you know monthly standups where people
are um encouraged to share learnings
like how how especially in a big
organization? Yeah. global organization.
How do you get those learnings from like
the small company here to the big unit
there ensure that like all those
learnings are leveraged across you know
the entire organization?
That's a great question and I feel like
it's not a cookie cutter approach to
everything. One thing that I really
struggled with when I first kind of
started taking this over is like who do
you invite to a meeting on AI? If you
think about that and you think about
like hey let's do a big global AI
meeting it's almost impossible because
if you think about you have people that
are just generally interested in AI and
want to be there want to listen want to
learn there's people that have specific
business cases but you might have a
finance business case and then you have
you know a newsroom business case and
they may not be like there's maybe some
things to share but also it's kind of
like maybe that person will be bored by
this particular topic. And then there
are practitioners, people that want to
go deep and technical and like nerd out
on the latest paper they're reading. And
so putting all those people in a room
and and curating an agenda for that
breath of audience is nearly impossible.
So what I found I have a couple
different things that I' I've deployed
is one is I have like a like a global
newsletter that goes out internally
where I kind of curate here's what's
happening in the business here's what's
happening in industry here's what's
happening kind of broad themes I'll kind
of pick and rotate different things and
that that serves to those you know that
are on the distribution list it's from
kind of some very senior executives to
people again that are just deeply
curious about AI then they get kind of a
swath and I was doing that I did that
for a year weekly because the pace of
things that were moving so fast. Then I
changed to bi-weekly and now we're at
monthly because I do have to maintain
some sanity.
I've put together like AI community as a
practice with a more technical audience
to kind of really again get into more
technical discussions. I've led
workshops and different cases depending
on the need and the subject. I just
recently helped the hack the finance
team and I went with them to do a global
hackathon on on AI. And so I don't think
there's a one-sizefits-all. And I
definitely don't think it's possible to
curate like for an organization as big
as ours and as many people who are now
involved with AI or just interested,
it's almost impossible to put them all
in a room and do one session that hits
all the points from like an executive
view to a practitioner builder view and
to just anyone who's interested. So, I
think you got to hit on a bunch of
different levels, a bunch of different
avenues. And then sometimes you've got
to pause some that, you know, from an
overhead may not make sense to continue
at a certain pace and find ways to to
get the message out. And sometimes it's
just really, like I said, connecting
people to people. I literally had
somebody email me
last night from Australia um and it was
like hey can you just connect me to you
know do you have a list of all the
people who are working at the business
um on AI and can you connect me to those
people and I said well do you want
technical people so this is kind of how
I framed it earlier like is it technical
people is it business people like is
there a certain like type of thing that
you want to know or learn so I had to
ask those questions so that I could say
oh you know what I'm going to go ahead
and introduce you to this person first
because if it's a business person here
and and immediately sent an email and
was like, "Hey guys, get together." So
sometimes it's literally just one-on-one
connections and that is part of what I I
bring is this kind of collaboration
connectivity to to what I do and how I
deploy strategy.
Whether it's in finance or the newsroom
or some other part of News Corp, is
there an approach to identifying the
best use cases for AI?
This one is so tricky for me because I
really struggle with when
we were just really starting out and
it's like what are our best lowhanging
fruit use cases and I sort of struggle
because it always feels like cart before
horse, right? or and it's like okay well
what are just the biggest problems in
our business regardless of whether or
not they can be solved with AI because
half the time or more than half the time
just sticking AI onto something is not
the solution or maybe it's traditional
ML AI and not Gen AI and so I feel like
sometimes there is a too much of a lean
into let's solve it with AI where the
question should be what are our biggest
problems or what are the problems that
we need solutions for now that are
really causing our our business to lose
money or be inefficient or that we could
see growth. So I I think it's hard to
say what are the best business cases for
or use cases for AI. Although I think
we've seen as a general trend. There are
some ones that broadly have been
easily applied. So like customer
service, knowledge management, like
those type of things like we're seeing
those use cases with CLA and OpenAI like
what they did and you're seeing you know
stories about AI generated coding as
different businesses leaning like X
percentage of our code is now done by AI
and we're seeing kind of shifts and
trends in those places. But I can't say
enough about how
just identify your problems first.
Understand the processes and the people
impacted by those processes and the the
metrics around it. Because I think too
um and we'll probably get to this later
is like you have to understand the time
something takes now or the amount of
money that is spent or the amount of
people that do X work to understand the
value ad of a solution. So that when you
get to, hey, we've we've tried
something, we've piloted something, you
can say definitively we're seeing x%
savings in time or
accuracy, etc. So that's a a very long
explanation for yes, there are some
tried and true use cases that I think
are definitely hitting across the board,
but I think most business should start
with just what are your biggest
problems? Yeah. And let's say you've
identified a problem. How is there a way
to prioritize
those problems that are worth solving
with AI versus those that are better
handled by process or policy? How do you
go from that problem to okay, let's
let's actually, you know, this is a good
fit for AI.
So this one again is a tangled web. you
ask very complex questions that I'm
going to have a complex answer for. So
in terms of I mean I I do think being
pretty methodical of understanding
the time something takes. I think
depending on the type of technology if
there was a really great use case I saw
recently where regulatory things that
come out quarterly regulatory is your
company compliant with this regulation.
So you have to scan all these really
dense compliance documentation and then
you have to understand the company. Does
the company need to meet any of these
criteria? And then you have to kind of
provide recommendations because you're
you're reviewing text and there's a lot
of time that a person would have to go
through to read and understand that
text. And then the output is a textbased
output, right? It's like yes, no kind of
qualification and then a natural
language description of what action
would you need to take as a company to
be compliant. Like to me, like that one
just made so much sense and you can then
understand how much would a single
person need to do to to each quarter
scan these these reports? How many
reports are there? So, I think there's
ones that just I don't know make sense.
But you you mentioned people and
process. I think on the flip side when
it comes to developing whatever solution
to the problem and if AI was the
recommended solution
even if those metrics match so say in
this case you can save a team of you
know reviewers and
50% of their time by giving them a set
of genai tools which will scan x amount
of documents and save them so much time
and then all they have to do is review
the outputs, make sure they're okay. The
problem I really still see is the change
management and the people side of
adopting these tools because I use this
phrase a lot. People are comforted by
their pain or like comfortable with
their pain is like I know that sometimes
I'm not the most efficient person when
it comes to doing a task, but I know how
to do this in my way. And for me to
change and adapt to like going to this
new system, learning these new things,
even if I know it will eventually save
me time, I have to go through this
learning process, which most people, you
know, are a little bit skeptical. Oh,
will this change me time? like you know
so I really do think that even if you
prove out that something is a good use
case you build the right thing people
are often forgetting the change
management and the people adoption side
of like successful implementations of
technology especially in this genai
world. So my word of caution to all,
don't forget about the change
management. Don't forget about the
adoption, the training needed to to
bring people along the journey because
if you're not bringing them along, it's
going to you're going to build
something, you're going to spend a lot
of money and it's not going to have the
added value you thought it was. Yeah.
When it comes to change management, are
there like some key learnings that
you've acred over the last couple years?
You mentioned, you know, training and
education and bringing people along. If
you had to distill like your philosophy
on change management into one answer to
a question, um what would it be?
think I think it it would be bringing
people on the journey like involve
people early
and get their input early because I
think if if you think about uh a user
group or like let's just say in a
hypothetical world um cuz this never
happens an executive gets in their head
that that they want to do something and
they think it's a great idea and they
tell you know a tech team or whatever
team build this thing it'll be great um
and they build it in a silo in a vacuum
because right the CEO is asking and like
that's a natural inclination to but if
you forget to involve the end users who
would be responsible for then using said
tool you you've missed
you've missed the mark and ultimately
they're probably going to have like I
think about like a a b like an organ
transplant they're probably going to
reject the organ or the tool right
because they're like you know it's
incompatible with my system. Now, it it
might be, but it's you you didn't you
didn't prep the body. You didn't te test
the blood work. You didn't check that
all the vitals were stable before you
inserted this new thing into their, you
know, work body. And so now they're
like, "No, no, it's poison. Let's shut
this Let's shut this down." So,
like that's I went weird to the metaphor
place right there, but hopefully it
struck a chord. We went to a weird
place, but I think we got to a point. I
like it. We're going to talk a little
bit about how you vet AI pitches, but
maybe before we do, how do you think
about the decision between building
internally or bringing in a vendor when
it comes to AI initiatives?
You know, it's funny because I don't
think anything's really changed. kind of
the same way about like use cases in
terms of the build versus buy like this
is a problem of all you know tech
builders um in a company. So I think
you want to build things that are let's
see closest to your core
your core business I guess. Um now it
doesn't have to be wholly built and
bespoke. um like there are great
partners with you know that we kind of
build and augment on top of um but I
think
with
build versus buy I think it's really
making sure if you're buying something
how much of it it the thing that you're
buying um needs to be unique or nuanced
for your business
and how much doesn't. Because
what I've seen is people say, "Okay,
yeah, I want that tool. It's 80% of what
I need." 20% will build on this special
thing. Sometimes that 20%
costs twice as much of of that out of
the box thing that you built and then
you have to replace that because now
you've almost made them incompatible.
So I think it's just really thinking
about the full
solution that you want to see and then
also do you have the right resources. I
think in the age of AI you know the top
talent is going to places like OpenAI,
Google and so you know there are really
talented data scientists out there and
that can help you build within your
company and we do have some really
amazing data scientists. Um but how much
can they even build because we have a
small percentage of those people. So how
much are they building uniquely? Are
they leveraging other tools? So, I think
I think it's it's still um
it's still a ways to to have I don't
have a perfect answer for that one, but
I think every company needs to to be
wary of, you know, what comes out of the
box, I guess, and how much I I guess my
biggest piece of advice though is like
is to urge people that do buy something
is really make sure the out of the box
that 80%
maybe really question whoever is asking
for that 20% special extra, what's the
value of that 20%. And can you just use
the out of the box? Because I would
guarantee that that 20% is going to slow
you down and it's going to make it
harder to maintain. It's going to make
it more complicated in the long run. So,
right, just use it out of the box. If
you are going to buy it, just use it as
as is. Now, that's an oversimplification
because obviously you will need some
special things um depending on your
business, but
lessons learned from some some
experiences. Let's let's talk about out
of the box solutions. You must get a lot
of AI pitches. Tell me a little bit
about the process you've developed to
separate the signal from the noise.
I'll give a story first and it's not a
very it may not be the nicest one about
me but I was in a vendor demo and about
maybe 10 minutes in I got some slideware
um and then they started demoing me an
HR chatbot and I feel like I've seen a
lot of HR chat bots as like here let us
show you what we can create and I just I
immediately was like you need to show me
something else because this just isn't
going to work for me. I've seen it. I
get you can create one, but I need you
to show me something different because
everyone's pitched that to me. So, I
guess that's a roundabout way of saying
that I often go into a room with most
vendors as being one of the most
skeptical people about why are you here?
What are you trying to sell me? Do you
have something that we really need? Are
you just putting up some vaporware? But
also I am one of the most optimistic
people about the potential of AI and it
being transformative. So if you show me
something that I I think could have
impact I will get excited and I will you
know try to socialize that across the
board but I get very tired of you know
seeing things that have sort of you oh
we've made this for somebody else and
you know you could use it. I'm like you
don't really understand our business.
So, one thing is if somebody's going to,
you know, come to a meeting with me and
my team, I can pretty much tell it's
sort of like doing a job interview with
an intern. Yeah. If they can't show that
they understand your company, they're
probably not going to be worth working
with. So, if somebody is just spending,
you know, 10 minutes just, you know,
probing me for for for my company. If
you haven't done some homework, that's a
concern. I also heard a story from a
co-orker who had gone to this vendor
meeting. It's supposed to be an AI
workshop and she got there was like,
"Okay, what what are the AI parts?" And
they literally just told her, "Oh, it's
it's not really AI. We just we just
called it." And so, you know, I I I do
think level setting with people. I see I
also do this a lot with vendors is
understand the vernacular. So, I see a
lot of people using Agentic and agents
and Agentic is still somewhat fuzzy
around the edges. So, I'll get into a
call be like, "What do you mean by
agents?" Like, give me your definition
because I'm not saying that like my
definition of agent is unchanging and
static, but I want to make sure that
we're speaking the same language and
have the same vernacular when it comes
to, you know, approaches and solutions,
you know, with AI. So those are some
things that I deploy. Maybe I don't
know. Is it mean to tell somebody not to
show me an HR chatbot? Should I if you
don't need it anymore? If you don't need
it, you know, just being honest. Yeah. C
can you tell us a little bit about and
you touched on this early earlier in our
conversation uh about ROI and the
importance of ROI when it comes to
whether it's a vendor that you're
purchasing software from or it's
something you're building. Tell us a
little bit about kind of how you think
about ROI and if there's a framework
that you've developed to assess it.
So I think one thing that
I am deeply conscious of is
while AI and the models are getting less
expensive every day right so the the
model cost you know gets tenfold
decrease in price you know fairly
rapidly AI solutions are still very
expensive to implement and not only that
what I'm seeing is that If for instance
you have a team that wants to build
let's let's use an HR chatbot you know
just as an example wants to build an HR
chatbot and they get you know sold by a
vendor and you know they're like this
we're going to build it for you know
it's going to be great.
I'm always making sure people understand
that okay yes I understand this will
save you time. How much is it going to
cost you to build it? How much is it
going to cost you to maintain it? How
often do you need to, you know, update
the model? How easily can you update the
model? Do you have an ability to move to
a lower cost model but not lose any of
the quality?
You know, these are all things that like
people are still trying to unpack and
understand. So I think in terms of
mapping it to a framework I think one
deeply understanding how your business
makes money and measures money measures
money we all measure money with like
dollars and cents but measures value is
really important. So like for instance
like subscriptions are a big part of of
our business and so understanding what
drives subscription growth and then
subscription growth in terms of equal
value like then you can map a solution
directly to those business drivers. So
mapping these things really in
specifically or you know if there's
business functions like more on the cost
savings. So subscriptions might be more
of a revenue generating model, right? So
that's where you would want to make sure
whatever your solution that's driving
revenue
maps very specifically back to are we
increasing subscription growth and can
we show show the math essentially. Yeah.
And then if you're looking at something
that's more cost savings, again, you
need to to understand the people and the
processes behind that to to a really
specific degree. you need to sit with
the teams and and get get your little
calculator out or get your spreadsheet
out and say, "Okay, I've got this amount
of people who are who are analyzing this
amount of content or and then that are
spending, you know, and they cost x
amount to have that and then to
understand with the solutions how you
can bring that cost down." So, you have
to do a pretty intensive mapping to get
it right because I think without that
intention, it's just sort of like like a
crystal ball and you're like, well, I
think the I hope the subscribers will
come. I hope I hope the cost savings
will come. Um, and I think that's
unfortunately, you know, not not the
smartest way to do business, but I think
I think we're all trying to get there.
Yeah. Let's talk a little bit about your
writing. You write a lot. Yeah, it's
good. Tell us about how AI shows up in
your creative workflow.
That's a great question. I I have like
all these ideas. I feel like I am that
person who has like a million thoughts
and would until recently sort of be like
I want to write a book or I want to
write something. But, you know, it it
takes a a lot more sit down time, a lot
more capacity than I thought I had.
With having AI tools at my disposal, I
can sort of take like an inkling of a
thought or I do this a lot where I'm
listening to an audio book and I'm like,
"Oo, I love this quote." And I'll take a
quote and I'll maybe throw it into chat
and I say like, "I I really love this."
and I'll I'll kind of um word vomit like
what I'm thinking about or what I'm
feeling that this makes me think of how
it excites me and I'll either like just
maybe ask like hey draft a LinkedIn post
that I might you know be able to share
this because I just I want to share this
or I'll I use it a lot. I'm I'm writing
a series on organizational intelligence
and so I'll you know I'll be driving
back from dropping my kids off from
school and I'll use the voice to text
and I'll be like I just had an idea for
a chapter you know blah blah blah blah
blah and again just plop it in as sort
of for now like like okay let me get the
ideas out in a space so JB has come
become somewhat of a notepad for me of
just all these stray thoughts that I can
now figure out how to focus them into an
intent or share kind of a little piece
of like Nicole's brain or like what I'm
reading or what I'm thinking um and how
I'm seeing and framing the world that I
didn't feel like I could as quickly or
as elegantly before. I still take a lot
of time to take that kernel of a
thought, you know, put it in chatb and
edit it quite a bit to still have the
essence of, you know, what is Nicole?
Because I do I see people post there's
so much AI slop out there. There's so
many LinkedIn posts that are all AI
generated and I believe that you know
everything I still put out there whether
I used AI to help me is still my
original thought. I had to think about
it, listen to it, hear it, put it into
an AI
chat and converse back. I often have
like several versions that I converse
even in
a chatbot before I even bring it into
like, you know, a word doc and then
further refine it and then I'll put it
in LinkedIn. I'll maybe do a final
polish. So, it takes a lot to kind of
get it there, but it just feels like it
gets me there faster. And I have like
almost like a like a friend or a coach
or somebody to kind of bounce ideas off
that before I felt like I had to sit in

and sort of hear my own echoes and not
get further than that little nugget.
Yeah. I was going to ask you like the
the difference between AI slop and using
AI to enable your own creativity. Um,
and it sounds like using it, as people
have said, as as a thought partner or as
a coach. Uh, I'm kind of curious, what
does that look like in practice? Are

that you could share that help take that

you know, a kind of like high quality
content piece?
So, I use a lot of different things and
I use a lot of different features within
some of the tools. So, I'll use projects
in, you know, chatbt or claude to kind
of set up and give it samples of my own
writing that I've done before. I also
just I'm a less is more prompter. So,
I'll sometimes just, you know, put in a
quote, give it some instructions, you
know, see what it comes out with. Maybe
I like it, maybe I don't. like no you
didn't really strike a chord there or
I'll take it offline I'll edit a little
bit throw it back and be like and now
polish this so I don't have a one set
technique I will also bounce between
tools so for instance I might brainstorm
a concept for a chapter in chat dbt I
might do kind of the initial like draft
in claude because I think the writing
style is a little better but then I
might go fact check myself in chat GBT
because sometimes Claude makes up quotes
or it'll make up stories of people like
or interactions that I've had for and
I'm like no no we're not going to do
that. Sometimes I'll put it into
Substack. I'll do all my edits, throw it
back in, you know. So it and sometimes
I'll put in chunks. Sometimes I'll put
in a full long form. I don't have like a
tried andrue method. I try a lot of
different things. Some of them work out
sometimes. I I love this one. LinkedIn
post. just add some emojis like like
that's that's one because you know I'm
just like yeah I need it to you know
look a little different or I'll I'll you
know ask it you know to leave space to
call people out so I'll know kind of
where I need to insert because it it
can't do some of that obviously but yeah
I'm I maybe don't have the most refined
approach but I have fun with it and I I
don't take it or myself too seriously.
Yeah. I mean, it sounds like the key
there is that it's iterative and that
it's not just ask and answer and use. It
is like ask and take and consume and
think and refine and create and ask
again and so on and so forth. Yeah. No,
I I think that's that's that's a the per
So, my perfect piece of advice now that
you've really brought this to life is
don't take don't ever take the first
draft. Like try at least one more draft.
You still might go back to to one of the
first ones or take a piece from this, a
piece from that, but never
never take the first draft and just post
it or or use it on its own because then
I do think it loses a bit of the the you
or the humanity because you still had to
give it the initial prompt to get that
that far, but I feel like you got to
iterate. Yeah. Yeah. I'd love to end
with some practical advice, a few
questions that hopefully,
you know, leverage some of your
experiences and learnings. And the first
is around product. Um, what's what's one
way that product leaders can start using
AI meaningfully today if they're not
already?
I mean I think for product leaders so
much of what we do is sort of written
discourse whether it's a email to
stakeholders or it's prepping a strategy
deck. I think it goes back to the advice
that I just gave on how to prompt is use
it as a collaborator. So the same way as
you be like you might have a first draft
of an email and you're just like is this
striking the right chord? throw it into
your company approved AI tool and say
like is this giving the right sentiment
like cross-check yourself or if you
would normally I remember years ago
before I would send like a very
important stakeholder email or have to
you know send something to a cranky
stakeholder I would have like a
co-worker like you know over my shoulder
be like hey can you read this one time
so think about it as the same thing the
same way you would work with a colleague
to sort of collect collaborate or to
brainstorm. You can do that now like
imagine or even use it as your first
draft. Use it as your first draft then
take it offline. So I think it's just
using it. I think the only other piece
of advice I would give is is be
skeptical about does this product andor
solution um need Genai? Does it need
just a new process? you know, because I
do think a lot of people are jumping to
must have an AI feature. Don't think
that's always the right use case or or
the right implementation is to just jump
straight to that. So, so be skeptical,
but use it all the time. I I feel like
I'm giving mixed messages, but in the
right way.
Yeah. Um I would love to talk lastly
about creativity. Uh you've used the
term AI amplified creativity. Uh we just

creative workflow. Do you think AI is
changing the definition of creativity
itself?
For me it is. Um I
have created AI songs with my daughter.
We create AI images with characters that
she references all the time. I would
never have done something that creative
or that kind of creative because I'm not
an artist. I'm not a song maker, but now
I can be. Yeah. I can teach my daughter
that, you know, she can be interested in
and dabble in a lot of things. I think
that's what's been really exciting for
me. I feel like I'm always curious um
about the world and learning new skills
and and different things. And so for me,
it gives me an opportunity to sort of
like dabble in these things or learn
about something that, you know, I was
worried would take me too much time, but
now, oh look, I can do a deep research
report on, you know, what it would be
like to move to Spain. Like, okay, like
that take a lot of time. I think it is.
It's definitely changing what creativity

of AI.
What a great place to end.
As promised, thank you Nicole for coming

cleanText:
Today on Just Curious, I'm joined by Nicole Castillo, Vice President of Strategic Products at News Corp, where she leads AI strategy across some of the world's biggest content and information businesses. But Nicole's also a writer, a mom, and a creative force of nature. In this episode, we'll explore how she blends AI into both her professional and personal life, from vendor vetting and business model strategy to writing Substack posts and bedtime stories with Chat GPT. Learn how she's building an AI ROI framework to cut through the noise of vendor hype, how she's piloting tools with the real benchmarks for success, and how she uses AI daily from streamlining finance operations to fast-tracking LinkedIn posts. Nicole, welcome to Just Curious.

I am very happy to be here and I'm very curious how this conversation's going to go. Appreciate your use of Curious. Um, Nicole, your bio calls you the Mary Poppins of product. Can you tell us the story behind that nickname and how it connects to your AI journey?

Sure. Um, so Mary confidence of product happened shortly after I joined News Corp. I had I don't even remember the the like exact moment, but I remember seeing something that caused me to be like, "Oh, that's totally me." I texted my old boss and I was like, "Isn't this me?" And he's like, "Totally." And it sort of stuck and I I leaned in really hard because it really is I think everyone when they think of Mary Poppins, they're like, "Oh, delightful." There's something about her that like you think is fun, but she's a little like hardedged, but like in a good way, like the best ways. And she has that magical bag of tricks and she just brings a lot of spoonful of sugar and super califragilistic expeladocious to everything. And I feel like that's totally me. Like I feel like if I can slip in a long word like that into any meeting and it just is really I think part of being scrappy, part of being creative, part of being curious about the world and bringing people on that journey. She brings these children along. I bring people stakeholders along with me on the magical journey that is you know creating wonderful products.

Curiosity and creativity obviously helpful when you're looking at something new like AI. Tell me how you got involved in helping News Corp understand and build a strategy to use AI.

Sadly accidentally. Um but I but I think it ultimately worked out and and there's a reason for it. Um I had actually just come back from my maternity leave for my second um child, my beautiful son, and things had changed. I had actually hired to lead mobile products. And I came back and I was like, I'm looking to to have more impact, do more things. And it was like, well, this new thing AI has become more of a a thing. Why don't you step into that? And so I started leaning into what do we do with AI? And much of my initial first steps were like just like uncovering the hype. It's like you're trying to like like is that real? Is that interesting? Is that important? Is that important for us for our business? And so I got the chance to really fall into it. But I think especially today where so much of the impact of AI is on people and is on experiences. I'm not saying it's less about the tech. There is definite need for data scientists and for people who have this really deeply technical skill to build these things, but so much of today is the democratization of AI and how people will use it. And I think product leaders, people leaders are ones to really help lead this new journey of AI for themselves, for their companies, for people within organizations.

Yeah. Why why do media companies care about AI? And and when I think about AI, obviously, and I believe News Corp and Dow Jones have been investing in AI for a long time, but when we're thinking about the next generation of AI, the generative AIs, the agentic AIs, the combination of traditional AI with new AI, why do media companies care about this future of AI?

Well, I think regardless of media or not, everyone should care because I think those who aren't moving into AI or aren't at least thinking about it are going to be left behind. I think media companies are more sensitive to it. There's obviously an IP angle to this. Large language models are powered by massive amounts of content to make them good and many of them have already used much of the content that is sort of out there. And so whatever new content is important to lead the next wave of great AI solutions and models. So I think you know media companies have this really important role to play in the future of how AI models get built and how they are getting better and how they'll really embed into the world. So I think but regardless I think every company should consider AI as an important part of where they take their business. Now it could be generative it could it could be something else but I think everyone should be deeply curious about how how AI could impact their companies. Yeah. Uh you work in a business with many business units. How do you coordinate AI strategy across so many brands and businesses, especially when priorities can differ?

Much like everyone who has jobs that are like hurting cats with great care and intention? Well, I I think, you know, we are in a really unique organization where not only do we have these amazing news brands, but we have real estate, we have book publishing, and like you said, there are different business needs that drive each of those businesses. Even in within the news businesses, there's different, you know, business models. And much of what it is is I'm a big connector. I connect the teams and the people that are are doing one thing and say, "By the way, do you know that this group is doing it and they're doing it really well?" and connecting those people and making sure that they're aware because ultimately we don't want duplication of you know if something is done really well you want to share that and that's the benefit of working in a large organization such such as news corporate somebody can take the lead and prove out and prove successful or prove something not successful and share the lessons learned for that journey or share the teaching so even you know one of our smaller business units who might be able to do more bleeding edge things with some of the AI models that some others cannot can still share. Oh, I had a lot of friction. For instance, you know, uh sensitive content. Many of the models have protection or guard rails against sensitive content. But news content has sometimes sensitive topics. And so, how do you get and work with models when some of those things are restricted? So, those are like little small lessons that I heard that in this one meeting with this one business unit and I managed to kind of help feed and filter that through the businesses. So it's creating that connective tissue more than it is you know pushing down a centralized mission and vision. We do have guard rails and principles in place on how to as a whole work and exist within kind of how you you build and use AI. I don't think there's any benefit to sort of like having a strong restriction on you know businesses leaning in and figuring out what works for them either.

Yeah. What have you learned in terms of the best ways to facilitate sharing it? Uh do you have a you know Slack channel and people are just dropping ideas in there? Do you set up you know monthly standups where people are um encouraged to share learnings like how how especially in a big organization? Yeah. global organization. How do you get those learnings from like the small company here to the big unit there ensure that like all those learnings are leveraged across you know the entire organization?

That's a great question and I feel like it's not a cookie cutter approach to everything. One thing that I really struggled with when I first kind of started taking this over is like who do you invite to a meeting on AI? If you think about that and you think about like hey let's do a big global AI meeting it's almost impossible because if you think about you have people that are just generally interested in AI and want to be there want to listen want to learn there's people that have specific business cases but you might have a finance business case and then you have you know a newsroom business case and they may not be like there's maybe some things to share but also it's kind of like maybe that person will be bored by this particular topic. And then there are practitioners, people that want to go deep and technical and like nerd out on the latest paper they're reading. And so putting all those people in a room and and curating an agenda for that breath of audience is nearly impossible. So what I found I have a couple different things that I' I've deployed is one is I have like a like a global newsletter that goes out internally where I kind of curate here's what's happening in the business here's what's happening in industry here's what's happening kind of broad themes I'll kind of pick and rotate different things and that that serves to those you know that are on the distribution list it's from kind of some very senior executives to people again that are just deeply curious about AI then they get kind of a swath and I was doing that I did that for a year weekly because the pace of things that were moving so fast. Then I changed to bi-weekly and now we're at monthly because I do have to maintain some sanity.
I've put together like AI community as a practice with a more technical audience to kind of really again get into more technical discussions. I've led workshops and different cases depending on the need and the subject. I just recently helped the hack the finance team and I went with them to do a global hackathon on on AI. And so I don't think there's a one-sizefits-all. And I definitely don't think it's possible to curate like for an organization as big as ours and as many people who are now involved with AI or just interested, it's almost impossible to put them all in a room and do one session that hits all the points from like an executive view to a practitioner builder view and to just anyone who's interested. So, I think you got to hit on a bunch of different levels, a bunch of different avenues. And then sometimes you've got to pause some that, you know, from an overhead may not make sense to continue at a certain pace and find ways to to get the message out. And sometimes it's just really, like I said, connecting people to people. I literally had somebody email me last night from Australia um and it was like hey can you just connect me to you know do you have a list of all the people who are working at the business um on AI and can you connect me to those people and I said well do you want technical people so this is kind of how I framed it earlier like is it technical people is it business people like is there a certain like type of thing that you want to know or learn so I had to ask those questions so that I could say oh you know what I'm going to go ahead and introduce you to this person first because if it's a business person here and and immediately sent an email and was like, "Hey guys, get together." So sometimes it's literally just one-on-one connections and that is part of what I I bring is this kind of collaboration connectivity to to what I do and how I deploy strategy.

Whether it's in finance or the newsroom or some other part of News Corp, is there an approach to identifying the best use cases for AI?

This one is so tricky for me because I really struggle with when we were just really starting out and it's like what are our best lowhanging fruit use cases and I sort of struggle because it always feels like cart before horse, right? or and it's like okay well what are just the biggest problems in our business regardless of whether or not they can be solved with AI because half the time or more than half the time just sticking AI onto something is not the solution or maybe it's traditional ML AI and not Gen AI and so I feel like sometimes there is a too much of a lean into let's solve it with AI where the question should be what are our biggest problems or what are the problems that we need solutions for now that are really causing our our business to lose money or be inefficient or that we could see growth. So I I think it's hard to say what are the best business cases for or use cases for AI. Although I think we've seen as a general trend. There are some ones that broadly have been easily applied. So like customer service, knowledge management, like those type of things like we're seeing those use cases with CLA and OpenAI like what they did and you're seeing you know stories about AI generated coding as different businesses leaning like X percentage of our code is now done by AI and we're seeing kind of shifts and trends in those places. But I can't say enough about how just identify your problems first. Understand the processes and the people impacted by those processes and the the metrics around it. Because I think too um and we'll probably get to this later is like you have to understand the time something takes now or the amount of money that is spent or the amount of people that do X work to understand the value ad of a solution. So that when you get to, hey, we've we've tried something, we've piloted something, you can say definitively we're seeing x% savings in time or accuracy, etc. So that's a a very long explanation for yes, there are some tried and true use cases that I think are definitely hitting across the board, but I think most business should start with just what are your biggest problems? Yeah. And let's say you've identified a problem. How is there a way to prioritize those problems that are worth solving with AI versus those that are better handled by process or policy? How do you go from that problem to okay, let's let's actually, you know, this is a good fit for AI.

So this one again is a tangled web. you ask very complex questions that I'm going to have a complex answer for. So in terms of I mean I I do think being pretty methodical of understanding the time something takes. I think depending on the type of technology if there was a really great use case I saw recently where regulatory things that come out quarterly regulatory is your company compliant with this regulation. So you have to scan all these really dense compliance documentation and then you have to understand the company. Does the company need to meet any of these criteria? And then you have to kind of provide recommendations because you're you're reviewing text and there's a lot of time that a person would have to go through to read and understand that text. And then the output is a textbased output, right? It's like yes, no kind of qualification and then a natural language description of what action would you need to take as a company to be compliant. Like to me, like that one just made so much sense and you can then understand how much would a single person need to do to to each


Quarter.
Scan these reports?
How many reports are there?
So, I think there's ones that just, I don't know, make sense.
But you mentioned people and process.
I think on the flip side when it comes to developing whatever solution to the problem, and if AI was the recommended solution, even if those metrics match, so say in this case, you can save a team of, you know, reviewers and 50% of their time by giving them a set of GenAI tools, which will scan x amount of documents and save them so much time, and then all they have to do is review the outputs, make sure they're okay.
The problem I really still see is the Change Management and the people side of adopting these tools because I use this phrase a lot.
People are comforted by their pain, or like comfortable with their pain, is like, I know that sometimes I'm not the most efficient person when it comes to doing a task, but I know how to do this in my way.
And for me to change and adapt to like going to this new system, learning these new things, even if I know it will eventually save me time, I have to go through this learning process, which most people, you know, are a little bit skeptical.
Oh, will this change me time?
Like, you know, so I really do think that even if you prove out that something is a good use case, you build the right thing, people are often forgetting the Change Management and the people adoption side of like successful implementations of technology, especially in this GenAI world.
So my word of caution to all, don't forget about the Change Management.
Don't forget about the adoption, the training needed to bring people along the journey because if you're not bringing them along, it's going to, you're going to build something, you're going to spend a lot of money, and it's not going to have the added value you thought it was.
Yeah.
When it comes to Change Management, are there like some key learnings that you've accrued over the last couple years?
You mentioned, you know, training and education and bringing people along.
If you had to distill like your philosophy on Change Management into one answer to a question, um, what would it be?
I think it would be bringing people on the journey, like involve people early and get their input early because I think if, if you think about a user group or like, let's just say in a hypothetical world, um, cuz this never happens, an executive gets in their head that that they want to do something, and they think it's a great idea, and they tell, you know, a tech team or whatever team, build this thing, it'll be great, um, and they build it in a silo, in a vacuum, because right, the CEO is asking, and like, that's a natural inclination to, but if you forget to involve the end users who would be responsible for then using said tool, you, you've missed, you've missed the mark, and ultimately, they're probably going to have like, I think about like a, a, like an organ transplant, they're probably going to reject the organ or the tool, right?
Because they're like, you know, it's incompatible with my system.
Now, it might be, but it's, you didn't, you didn't prep the body.
You didn't test the blood work.
You didn't check that all the vitals were stable before you inserted this new thing into their, you know, work body.
And so now they're like, "No, no, it's poison.
Let's shut this, let's shut this down."
So, like that's, I went weird to the metaphor place right there, but hopefully it struck a chord.
We went to a weird place, but I think we got to a point.
I like it.
We're going to talk a little bit about how you vet AI pitches, but maybe before we do, how do you think about the decision between building internally or bringing in a vendor when it comes to AI initiatives?
You know, it's funny because I don't think anything's really changed.
I'm kind of the same way about like use cases in terms of the build versus buy, like this is a problem of all, you know, tech builders, um, in a company.
So I think you want to build things that are, let's see, closest to your core, your core business, I guess.
Um, now it doesn't have to be wholly built and bespoke.
Um, like there are great partners with, you know, that we kind of build and augment on top of, um, but I think with build versus buy, I think it's really making sure if you're buying something, how much of it, the thing that you're buying, um, needs to be unique or nuanced for your business and how much doesn't.
Because what I've seen is people say, "Okay, yeah, I want that tool.
It's 80% of what I need."
20% will build on this special thing.
Sometimes that 20% costs twice as much of that out of the box thing that you built, and then you have to replace that because now you've almost made them incompatible.
So I think it's just really thinking about the full solution that you want to see, and then also, do you have the right resources?
I think in the age of AI, you know, the top talent is going to places like OpenAI, Google, and so, you know, there are really talented data scientists out there and that can help you build within your company, and we do have some really amazing data scientists.
Um, but how much can they even build because we have a small percentage of those people?
So how much are they building uniquely?
Are they leveraging other tools?
So, I think, I think it's, it's still, um, it's still a ways to, to have, I don't have a perfect answer for that one, but I think every company needs to be wary of, you know, what comes out of the box, I guess, and how much, I, I guess my biggest piece of advice though, is like, is to urge people that do buy something, is really make sure the out of the box, that 80%, maybe really question whoever is asking for that 20% special extra, what's the value of that 20%?
And can you just use the out of the box?
Because I would guarantee that that 20% is going to slow you down, and it's going to make it harder to maintain.
It's going to make it more complicated in the long run.
So, right, just use it out of the box.
If you are going to buy it, just use it as is.
Now, that's an oversimplification, because obviously you will need some special things, um, depending on your business, but lessons learned from some experiences.
Let's talk about out of the box solutions.
You must get a lot of AI pitches.
Tell me a little bit about the process you've developed to separate the signal from the noise.
I'll give a story first, and it's not a very, it may not be the nicest one about me, but I was in a vendor demo, and about maybe 10 minutes in, I got some slideware, um, and then they started demoing me an HR chatbot, and I feel like I've seen a lot of HR chatbots, as like, here, let us show you what we can create, and I just, I immediately was like, you need to show me something else because this just isn't going to work for me.
I've seen it.
I get you can create one, but I need you to show me something different because everyone's pitched that to me.
So, I guess that's a roundabout way of saying that I often go into a room with most vendors as being one of the most skeptical people about why are you here?
What are you trying to sell me?
Do you have something that we really need?
Are you just putting up some vaporware?
But also, I am one of the most optimistic people about the potential of AI and it being transformative.
So if you show me something that I, I think could have impact, I will get excited, and I will, you know, try to socialize that across the board, but I get very tired of, you know, seeing things that have sort of, you know, oh, we've made this for somebody else, and, you know, you could use it.
I'm like, you don't really understand our business.
So, one thing is, if somebody's going to, you know, come to a meeting with me and my team, I can pretty much tell, it's sort of like doing a job interview with an intern.
Yeah.
If they can't show that they understand your company, they're probably not going to be worth working with.
So, if somebody is just spending, you know, 10 minutes just, you know, probing me for, for, for my company, if you haven't done some homework, that's a concern.
I also heard a story from a co-worker who had gone to this vendor meeting.
It's supposed to be an AI workshop, and she got there, was like, "Okay, what, what are the AI parts?"
And they literally just told her, "Oh, it's, it's not really AI.
We just, we just called it."
And so, you know, I, I, I do think level setting with people.
I see, I also do this a lot with vendors, is understand the vernacular.
So, I see a lot of people using Agentic and agents, and Agentic is still somewhat fuzzy around the edges.
So, I'll get into a call, be like, "What do you mean by agents?"
Like, give me your definition, because I'm not saying that like my definition of agent is unchanging and static, but I want to make sure that we're speaking the same language and have the same vernacular when it comes to, you know, approaches and solutions, you know, with AI.
So those are some things that I deploy.
Maybe I don't know.
Is it mean to tell somebody not to show me an HR chatbot?
Should I, if you don't need it anymore?
If you don't need it, you know, just being honest.
Yeah.
Can you tell us a little bit about, and you touched on this early earlier in our conversation, uh, about ROI and the importance of ROI when it comes to whether it's a vendor that you're purchasing software from or it's something you're building?
Tell us a little bit about kind of how you think about ROI and if there's a framework that you've developed to assess it.
So I think one thing that I am deeply conscious of is, while AI and the models are getting less expensive every day, right?
So the, the model cost, you know, gets tenfold decrease in price, you know, fairly rapidly, AI solutions are still very expensive to implement, and not only that, what I'm seeing is that, if, for instance, you have a team that wants to build, let's, let's use an HR chatbot, you know, just as an example, wants to build an HR chatbot, and they get, you know, sold by a vendor, and, you know, they're like, this, we're going to build it for, you know, it's going to be great.
I'm always making sure people understand that, okay, yes, I understand this will save you time.
How much is it going to cost you to build it?
How much is it going to cost you to maintain it?
How often do you need to, you know, update the model?
How easily can you update the model?
Do you have an ability to move to a lower cost model, but not lose any of the quality?
You know, these are all things that like people are still trying to unpack and understand.
So I think in terms of mapping it to a framework, I think one, deeply understanding how your business makes money and measures money, measures money, we all measure money with like dollars and cents, but measures value is really important.
So like, for instance, like subscriptions are a big part of our business, and so understanding what drives subscription growth, and then subscription growth in terms of equal value, like then you can map a solution directly to those business drivers.
So mapping these things really in specifically, or, you know, if there's business functions, like more on the cost savings.
So subscriptions might be more of a revenue generating model, right?
So that's where you would want to make sure whatever your solution that's driving revenue maps very specifically back to, are we increasing subscription growth, and can we show, show the math, essentially?
Yeah.
And then if you're looking at something that's more cost savings, again, you need to understand the people and the processes behind that to a really specific degree.
You need to sit with the teams and and get, get your little calculator out or get your spreadsheet out and say, "Okay, I've got this amount of people who are who are analyzing this amount of content, or and then that are spending, you know, and they cost x amount to have that, and then to understand with the solutions how you can bring that cost down."
So, you have to do a pretty intensive mapping to get it right, because I think without that intention, it's just sort of like, like a crystal ball, and you're like, well, I think the, I hope the subscribers will come.
I hope, I hope the cost savings will come.
Um, and I think that's, unfortunately, you know, not, not the smartest way to do business, but I think, I think we're all trying to get there.
